summary:
Meta values honesty. She loves art, enjoys nature and is fascinated by change.

Meta is also a curious, analytical thinker, always content-driven and value-based. She loves to write essays, curate exhibitions, moderate debates and do lectures, and also fancies to pioneer new projects. As a leader, she is inspirational, strategic and adventurous, as well as results-oriented, transparent and reliable. She always chooses collaboration over competition, enjoying to work with diverse ranges of people, sharing their talents, passion and experience.   

Meta has her own business at the crossroads of culture, science and society. As an art historian and former director of Museum De Lakenhal in Leiden, she generates change in the museum sector, and beyond. Her focus is on contemporary art, museums, arts & science and anything interdisciplinary or out-of-the-box. As a former director of Leiden European City of Science 2022 - a pilot project of the European Commission - she is engaged in exploring new models for Public Engagement with Science, aimed at connecting science with society. As one of the founders of the Ministry of the Future, she is keen on implementing innovative, bottom-up methods for future design. 

Within these future-oriented strategies, Meta pursues deep connections between the past and the present. Being aware of the world we share, in both her work and personal life she is committed to nature preservation and intergenerational justice. With her family, she lives on a farm near Leiden, where they keep a cattle of Lakenvelder-cows (Dutch living heritage) and maintain 36 acres of agri-ecological land.

projects.description:
What does it mean to be forced to flee your home and become internally displaced? What is the meaning of the word ‘home’ in the context of war, diaspora, exclusion, and displacement? These questions are central to the exhibition HOME, curated by Meta Knol, with photographic works by Dutch artist Marjan Teeuwen – Destroyed House Gaza – and videoblogs made by Palestinian photographer Ezz Al Zanoon and journalist Rawan Mahady.

projects.description:
Pleinmuseum was an architectural sculpture, a mobile pavilion supporting multiscreen video installations. Placed in the public sphere of town squares, this innovative project at the time contributed to the debate about contemporary museum practice. Designer René van Engelenburg proposed a radical reversal of the Amsterdam 'Museumplein' (museum square) into Pleinmuseum (square museum). He envisioned an innovative, white cube that was completely closed during the day and only opened to the public at sunset, hydraulically and computer-controlled. The pavilion functioned as a chameleonic object whose skin absorbed contemporary art works within the context of the public space. The installation raised one of the first major 'public video art conversations' in the Netherlands.

In the period 2004-2007, Pleinmuseum traveled around several European cities. In each of those, new digital artworks were added to its collection. The tour went to Utrecht, Amsterdam, Rotterdam, Middelburg, Groningen, Tilburg, Antwerp, Paris, Milan and Venice.

In 2007 Pleinmuseum was part of the programming of the British pavilion during the 52nd Venice Biennale. The same year, it was part of the public programming of the Nuit Blanche in Paris.

Partners: Zeeland Nazomerfestival, Noorderzon festival, Bureau Cultuurmakelaar Tilburg, Museum voor Schone Kunsten Antwerpen, Nuit Blanche Parijs, Domus Italia, Arts Council England, TATE Britain

Artists and designers: Piet Rogie, P. Struycken, Merlijn Twaalfhoven, Peter Missotten, Driessens / Verstappen, Gido Leijtens, Arnoud van den Heuvel, LADDS, Niels Schrader, Amir Admoni, Roel Wouters, Bea de Visser, Geert Mul, Martijn Engelbregt

Curator 2005-2006: Meta Knol
Curators 2007: Edwin Jacobs, Anne van der Zwaag, Meta Knol

profile_positions.description:
Meta Knol heeft een uniek profiel op het kruisvlak van cultuur, wetenschap en samenleving. Ze is actief als auteur, dagvoorzitter, gastconservator en inhoudelijk-strategisch adviseur, steevast met het oog gericht op een duurzame toekomst. Als kunsthistorica is ze gespecialiseerd in moderne en hedendaagse kunst en mengt ze zich graag in debatten over museale vernieuwing. Als directeur van Museum De Lakenhal was ze verantwoordelijk voor de vernieuwing en alom geprezen restauratie en uitbreiding van het Leidse museum (2019). Als directeur van Leiden European City of Science 2022, één van de tien excellente projecten van het wetenschappelijke HorizonEurope programma, ontwikkelde ze een nieuw, bottom-up model voor Public Engagement with Science. Als mede-oprichter van het Ministerie van de Toekomst, een landelijke beweging van tijdrebellen en kathedraaldenkers, richt ze zich op nieuwe, toekomstgerichte vormen van civic design. In 2024 komt Meta's boek uit bij Walburg Pers: het Handboek voor Tijdreizigers.

Meta Knol has a unique profile at the intersection of culture, science and society. As an author, moderator, guest curator and content-strategic advisor, she always keeps a keen eye on a sustainable future. As an art historian, she specializes in modern and contemporary art and actively participates in debates about museum innovation. As director of Museum De Lakenhal in Leiden, she was responsible for the integral renewal and the widely acclaimed restoration and expansion (2019). As director of Leiden European City of Science 2022, one of the ten excellent projects of the HorizonEurope programme, she developed a new, bottom-up model for Public Engagement with Science. As co-founder of the Ministry of the Future, a national movement of time rebels and cathedral thinkers, she focuses on new, future-oriented forms of civic design. In 2024, Meta's book will be published by Walburg Pers: the Handbook for Time Travelers.

profile_positions.description:
Leiden European City of Science 2022 was a 365-day science festival packed with activities, lectures, workshops, excursions, exhibitions, and events, for anyone with a curious mind, with the overall aim to connect science and society.

The year was officially opened on January 22 by the Dutch Minister for Education, Culture and Science Robbert Dijkgraaf and EU-Commissioner Mariya Gabriel. Leiden2022 presented the 10th edition of the EuroScience Open Forum (ESOF), the 33rd final of the EU Contest for Young Scientists and the very first edition of the EU Talenton, a brand-new EU-mission based science-hackathon for early career researchers. Moreover, during Leiden2022, over 100 scientific conferences took place, and many more activities were developed in Leiden, The Netherlands, and beyond. 

The year-long local co-creation project Knowledge throughout the Neighbourhoods built bridges between science and local society, sharing science, knowledge, art and expertise in the capillaries of Leiden and the region. The activities were organised by neighbourhood associations, residents, the education sector or representatives of social organisations. For scientists who wanted to participate, there were only two rules: step out of our institute and do not give a lecture! That way, everyone was challenged to share their knowledge in different, playful ways. Based on a calender with 365 topics, some 206 small-scaled, bottom-up activities took place. 

Leiden was the very first European city to present a 365 days science festival, as part of the European Research Area Policy Agenda, Action 14: Bring Science Closer to Citizens. As such, Leiden2022 has developed a new Model for Public Engagement with Science: a scalable co-creation method to spark playful interactions between scientists and citizens, aimed at connecting science with society. 

With this remarkable year, Leiden2022 pioneered a new, European tradition: in 2024, Katowice in Poland will be the European City of Science.

profile_positions.description:
Museum De Lakenhal is both a classical, elegant institute dating from 1874 and an adventurous, contemporary public space. The museum has a long history, an outstanding collection and a motivated and competent staff. The museum stands out with the refreshing, scientific and visual quality of its exhibitions and collection presentations. Museum De Lakenhal offers its visitors an experience across eras - taking them on an adventure through the ages to the present. 

The old 'Laecken-Halle' is a clothmakers’ hall built in 1640. As a museum, it houses art, decorative arts and historical relics of Dutch urban culture dating from the 16th century to the present. The Dutch Golden Age is known for its profound influence on the art world, and Museum De Lakenhal is a rich repository of these pieces - including works from the young Rembrandt, as well as remarkable canvases from the Leiden Fijnschilders or ‘fine-painters’ school. Alongside the paintings are superior collections of silver, glass, textiles and period furniture, allowing visitors to truly take a stroll through history. Yet the collection does not focus solely on the past, but rather has been built to include extraordinary works of contemporary art as well. 

In June 2019 the transformation process of Museum De Lakenhal was crowned with the grand reopening of the restored and expanded museum by King Willem Alexander. The noble simplicity of the 17th Century cloth hall had been restored to its former glory and a brandnew exhibition wing was added. Since then, the renewed Museum De Lakenhal has won a great deal of Dutch architecture prizes, and was recently also nominated for the European Museum of the Year Award.

Framer Framed is an Amsterdam based platform for contemporary art, visual culture, and critical theory & practice. Each year the organisation presents a variety of exhibitions, in collaboration with both emerging and established international curators and artists, on topics such as identity politics, notions of ‘the Other’, and historiographical propositions. An extensive public program is organised alongside these exhibitions in order to shed light on the topics concerned, and provide a wide range of perspectives. With this common space for dialogue, Framer Framed aims to show a plurality of voices in a globalized society.

In 1976 is, naar aanleiding van de uitbreiding van het hoofdkantoor  in Hoevelaken,  besloten om kunst te gaan verzamelen. Al vanaf de start werd er internationaal verzameld. Het doel was een afspiegeling van de actuele kunst te verzamelen. Inmiddels bestaat de collectie uit ruim 1000 kunstwerken en is het zwaartepunt van de collectie komen te liggen op hedendaagse (inter-)nationale kunst waarin ruimte een rol speelt. De collectie is nadrukkelijk verbonden met het bedrijf en haar medewerkers.

https://www.verenigingrembrandt.nl/959/

Vijftienduizend kunstliefhebbers samen, dat is de Vereniging Rembrandt. Al 134 jaar zet dit collectieve mecenaat zich in voor de versterking en bescherming van de Collectie Nederland.
Wij vinden het belangrijk dat ook de generaties na ons kunnen genieten van topkunst in ons land. Daarom steunen wij Nederlandse musea bij belangrijke kunstaankopen en maken ons sterk voor het behoud van het openbare kunstbezit. Vereniging Rembrandt heeft sinds haar oprichting in 1883 bijgedragen aan de aankoop van vele belangrijke en inmiddels onmisbare werken die nu voor iedereen toegankelijk zijn.

MU is an explorative presentation platform that operates in a rich international network of creatives who define the liminal space between ‘what art is and what art can be’.
MU initiates, produces and presents rather new works, and surrounds it with an extensive and interdisciplinary secondary program targeted to a broad and rather young audience. 
MU prioritises introduction to, understanding of, elaboration on, and experiencing hands-on creation, of art.
MU is curious for talent, and challenges talents to be curious. 
MU provides a platform for artistic research, and development of artists and designers, and helps them to profile themselves internationally.
MU is located in a former Philips factory at Strijp-S in Eindhoven, The Netherlands.

volunteer_experiences.description:
http://www.vijfde-seizoen.nl/en/

Het Vijfde Seizoen (The Fifth Season) is a residence for artists in psychiatry. Professional artists work here for a season. Since 1998 many artists have worked in Het Vijfde Seizoen. It is an inspiring place. The line between sick or not sick sometimes seems to disappear for the artists and the patients. It is remarkable to see how each artist picks his own angle and approaches the psychiatry from a totally personal point of view. By inviting a different artist every season to work at the residency, a contribution is made to our goal of bringing society closer to psychiatry. Through their works of art the artists contribute to the imaging of the psychiatric patient and psychiatry in general.

Curiosity drives. Our musical world is like a flea market, a bazaar, an attic full of stuff waiting to be explored. Our ears love strange sounds and instruments. They trigger questions on style, genre, instrumentation: ‘What if we could…?’.

Curiosity embraces. Our art is all about incorporation: acquired knowledge and fresh insight are respectfully transformed into something new. Other art forms may enter our stage.

Curiosity communicates. After a lot of preparation, we allow our improvisational qualities to take over. An ultimate form of musical thinking, not limited to the jazz tradition. We like our performances to make the audience an active partner in the creative moment.

volunteer_experiences.description:
Every year 250 students and an equal number of non-students participate in the Veer Foundation Symposium. The students are generally in the final phase of their studies and come from Dutch and Flemish universities and colleges. The aim is to have as diverse a group of student participants as possible, in terms of discipline and location. The students are selected by a jury of professors on the basis of a thematic essay. We call the 250 participating non-students 'shapers of society'. This group includes people from the business community, government, science, art, interest groups and the media. In order to guarantee the quality and relevance of the exchange of views, the Foundation targets the 'shapers of society' and invites them personally to attend. In this group, too, diversity is sought so that the meeting between all participants, young and old, will be refreshing and inspiring through the combination of different perspectives. The Feather Foundation is about unique interaction: getting to know each other, sharing visions and learning from each other. In addition, we create a space where generations can inspirew one another. In this way, shapers can contribute to the personal development of the new generation. Here lies the value of participating in this unique union of generations.

👇🏾

The Hope Foundation is working in the Palestinian territories. By offering playful lessons in the fields of art and culture HOPE aims to help traumatized and handicapped children to build a meaningful life for themselves. HOPE envisions a future where children are able to cope with the effects of war in the best way possible and where the basic requirements for leading a life that is worthwhile are available to all. For the Khan Younis Open Studio team, which offers the lessons in art and culture, HOPE acts as a source of inspiration and as initiator for projects, such as BeeHome Academy, the Breakdance Academy and the Summer Camps.

Het Ministerie van de Toekomst is als bottom-up initiatief gestart in een tijd van grote en complexe maatschappelijke verandering. We agenderen het langetermijndenken ('kathedraaldenken') in de samenleving en behartigen de belangen van toekomstige generaties in denken en doen.
Het Ministerie is niet links of rechts, want de toekomst is van iedereen. Als zwerm van burgers en professionals organiseren we door het hele land Plekberaden, Themaberaden en creatieve interventies die de toekomst dichterbij brengen.
